name: Literature & Digital Culture
long_desc: This course will study points of encounter between digital technologies and literature. With an eye on questions pertaining to the ontology of literature and literary meaning, we will survey the various digital tools and resources that have transformed practices of reading, writing, and critical response in the 21st century. At the same time, we will also explore the benefits of applying a humanitiesbased analysis to the digital age. Marshaling techniques from media studies, cultural studies, literary studies, and the digital humanities, we will address pressing questions about the increasingly prominent role of the digital in our daily lives. What threats does computerization pose to literary discourse How can we leverage the tremendous potential of new technologies to promote creativity, inclusivity, and mutual understanding What and how does literature mean in a digital age To complement our collective investigation, students will complete smallstakes, entrylevel assignments that introduce digital affordances for engaging with literary texts. No previous experience with the digital humanities is necessary to participate. Technological neophytes, seasoned programmers, and persons at all skill levels inbetween are all very welcome to participate. This course meets the Dietrich College Reflecting Gen Ed requirement.

custom_fields.goals: 1 To consider the impact of digital technologies on literary study, the production of literature, and the processes of literary meaning. 2 To engage questions of meaning and interpretation that attend to the intersection of technology and literature. 3 To hone key skills pertaining to humanities scholarship research, critical writing, appraisal, argumentation, discussion, presentation.
custom_fields.key_topics: media studies, digital humanities, cultural studies, literature, cultural analytics
custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge: Basic familiarity with university-level literary studies at this level... No previous experience with the digital humanities is necessary to participate. Technological neophytes, seasoned programmers, and persons at all skill levels in-between are all very welcome to participate.
custom_fields.assessment_structure: essay assignments, short, informal writing assignments online, class presentations
custom_fields.relevance: The course emphasizes the study of history, society, and culture from local and global perspectives and it investigates contemporary societies alongside societies of the past, canvassing a rich array of cultural products, artifacts, and ideas.
custom_fields.learning_resources: course website, digital resources through the CMU library
custom_fields.extra_time_commitment: students will have to budget time for class readings and written assignments
